active_learning.discussion_prompt: Debate whether prioritizing DER reduction justifies slowing down release cycles. Use NIST SSDF (SP 800-218) practices as reference, considering real-world examples like Log4Shell or Heartbleed as escaped defects.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Software Development Security metrics. Topic: Defect Escape Rate (DER) in hierarchy Cybersecurity > Software Development Security > Software Security Effectiveness > 009_Security Metrics and Measurement > Quality and Defect Metrics > Defect Escape Rate. Incorporate these exactly: - Learning Objectives: [INSERT FULL LIST FROM ABOVE] - Active Learning: [INSERT FULL DETAILS FROM ABOVE] - Scaffolding Layers: [INSERT FULL DETAILS FROM ABOVE] - Best Practices: Shift-left security (SAST, DAST, IAST), penetration testing, peer reviews, continuous monitoring, incident response integration, CI/CD gates. Target DER <5%. Examples: Log4Shell, Heartbleed. - Sources: NIST SP 800-218 SSDF v1.1 (https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.SP.800-218), OWASP SAMM, ISO/IEC 27034. - Concept Map: Central DER → SDLC phases (pre/post defects) → Factors (testing types) → Outcomes (risk reduction). - Formula: DER = (Post-release security defects / Total SDLC security defects) × 100%. Generate 25 flashcards following the exact schema: Front: Question (MCQ, 4 options). Back: {answer: '**Correct**', explanation: '...', connections: '...', bloom_level: '...'} Balance: 5 per scaffolding layer, spanning Bloom's levels. Use distractor protocol. Ensure university pedagogy: active recall, spaced repetition friendly, ties to objectives/activities. Output as JSON array of objects.
